elements.content: A novel one-dimensional (1D) metal−organic nanotube {[Cd2(ADC)2(bpp)3(H2O)]2·8H2O} n (MONT-1), based on mixed organic ligands, has been synthesized and characterized. MONT-1 presents the first independent 1D metal−organic nanotube with mesohelical structure and a fascinating topology of 1D → 2D interdigital architecture with side arms. This compound also exhibits high thermal stability and blue-shift emission with large intensity enhancement compared with that of the free ligand and can be explored for potential blue luminescent materials.
elements.clean_text: A novel one-dimensional (1D) metal-organic nanotube {[Cd2(ADC)2(bpp)3(H2O)]2⋅8H2O} n  (MONT-1), based on mixed organic ligands, has been synthesized and characterized. MONT-1 presents the first independent 1D metal-organic nanotube with mesohelical structure and a fascinating topology of 1D → 2D interdigital architecture with side arms. This compound also exhibits high thermal stability and blue-shift emission with large intensity enhancement compared with that of the free ligand and can be explored for potential blue luminescent materials.

elements.content: A novel one-dimensional (1D) metal−organic nanotube {[Cd2(ADC)2(bpp)3(H2O)]2·8H2O} n (MONT-1) has been synthesized and characterized. MONT-1 presents the first independent 1D metal−organic nanotube with mesohelical structure and a fascinating topology of 1D → 2D interdigital architecture with side arms. This compound also exhibits high thermal stability and blue-shift emission with large intensity enhancement compared with that of the free ligand and can be explored for potential blue luminescent materials.
elements.clean_text: A novel one-dimensional (1D) metal-organic nanotube {[Cd2(ADC)2(bpp)3(H2O)]2⋅8H2O} n  (MONT-1) has been synthesized and characterized. MONT-1 presents the first independent 1D metal-organic nanotube with mesohelical structure and a fascinating topology of 1D → 2D interdigital architecture with side arms. This compound also exhibits high thermal stability and blue-shift emission with large intensity enhancement compared with that of the free ligand and can be explored for potential blue luminescent materials.

elements.content: Helices are of intense interest because living organisms utilize them to store and transmit genetic information such as protein bundles and DNA prevalent in biological systems. Many chemists have made great contributions to this field, and it remains an interesting research field to rationally design and construct helical coordination polymers based upon the self-assembly of metal ions and multifunctional organic ligands. Recently, some single-, double-, triple-, and higher-order helical complexes have been obtained. However, mesohelical motifs are very rare, although mesohelices are widespread in nature, such as the tendrils of a variety of plants. Up to now, only a few one-dimensional (1D) mesohelical coordination polymers have been reported, which can be viewed as a three-dimensional (3D) presentation of a lemniscate. In this communication, we report a novel 1D mesohelical Cd(II) polymer possessing an independent metal−organic nanotube (MONT).
elements.clean_text: Helices are of intense interest because living organisms utilize them to store and transmit genetic information such as protein bundles and DNA prevalent in biological systems. Many chemists have made great contributions to this field, and it remains an interesting research field to rationally design and construct helical coordination polymers based upon the self-assembly of metal ions and multifunctional organic ligands. Recently, some single-, double-, triple-, and higher-order helical complexes have been obtained. However, mesohelical motifs are very rare, although mesohelices are widespread in nature, such as the tendrils of a variety of plants. Up to now, only a few one-dimensional (1D) mesohelical coordination polymers have been reported, which can be viewed as a three-dimensional (3D) presentation of a lemniscate. In this communication, we report a novel 1D mesohelical Cd(II) polymer possessing an independent metal-organic nanotube (MONT).

elements.content: Since the discovery of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) in the 1890s, many nanotubular structures have been synthesized. Recently, considerable progress has been made in the design and synthesis of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) with channels that are highly active areas of investigation because of their intriguing structures and, more importantly, their potential applications in gas storage, molecular sieves, ion exchange, and catalysis. Unlike CNTs, it is difficult to design and synthesize nanotubular MOFs with a structure similar to the CNTs, because of the variety and complexity of coordination modes. So far, many MOFs with open channels have been synthesized, but only a few nanotubular MOFs have been documented in the literature. For example, Hong’s group have synthesized a nanotubular Ag(I) complex constructed from a flexible tripodal ligand and a Cd(II) compound based on mixed organic ligands. A Zn(II) tubular MOF based on a 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole ligand has been reported by Zur Loye and co-workers. Besides, a nanotubular heterometallic {[Ln(dipic)3Mn1.5(H2O)3]·nH2O} MOF has also been designed and synthesized. However, all the nanotubular units in the MOFs mentioned above only act as subunits, which are further bridged by other ligands to build a highly dimensional struture; the independent 1D MONTs are quite rare. Therefore, it is a great challenge to synthesize independent 1D MONTs.
elements.clean_text: Since the discovery of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) in the 1890s, many nanotubular structures have been synthesized. Recently, considerable progress has been made in the design and synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with channels that are highly active areas of investigation because of their intriguing structures and, more importantly, their potential applications in gas storage, molecular sieves, ion exchange, and catalysis. Unlike CNTs, it is difficult to design and synthesize nanotubular MOFs with a structure similar to the CNTs, because of the variety and complexity of coordination modes. So far, many MOFs with open channels have been synthesized, but only a few nanotubular MOFs have been documented in the literature. For example, Hong's group have synthesized a nanotubular Ag(I) complex constructed from a flexible tripodal ligand and a Cd(II) compound based on mixed organic ligands. A Zn(II) tubular MOF based on a 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole ligand has been reported by Zur Loye and co-workers. Besides, a nanotubular heterometallic {[Ln(dipic)3Mn1.5(H2O)3]⋅nH2O} MOF has also been designed and synthesized. However, all the nanotubular units in the MOFs mentioned above only act as subunits, which are further bridged by other ligands to build a highly dimensional struture; the independent 1D MONTs are quite rare. Therefore, it is a great challenge to synthesize independent 1D MONTs.

elements.content: In order to design 1D MONTs, the linking mode of the organic ligand should accord with the coordination geometry of the metal ion. An effective strategy for this is that the organic ligands first link metal ions to generate a polygon as the subunit, and then, the subunits are connected to the second organic ligands to form a 1D nanotubular framework. By using this synthetic strategy, Sun and co-workers have reported an attractive {[Zn(ATIBDC)(bpy)]·3H2O} n [ATIBDC =5-amino-2,4,6-triiodoisophthalic] MONT with a squares framework. Lately, a novel {[Cd3(phen)3(HL)2(H2O)2]·4.25H2O} n [HL =4,4′-(1,4-phenylene)bis(2,6-dimethyl-3,5-pyridinedi-carboxylic acid)] MONT with 63 topology also has been reported by Huang and co-workers. 1,3-Adamantanedicarboxylic acid (H2ADC) is a V-shaped ligand, and the angle between the coordinating sites is ca. 110° and can be used effectively for the construction of a polygon, which enhances the possibility of formation of a nanotubular framework. However, on the basis of mixed organic ligands, constructing independent 1D MONTs usually requires a terminal ligand as the secondary ligand. A long flexible ligand (bpp) acts as the secondary ligand to construct an independent one-dimensional MONT which has not been reported before. We herein present a novel {[Cd2(ADC)2(bpp)3(H2O)]2·8H2O} n (MONT-1) [bpp =1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane], which is, to our knowledge, the first example of a mesohelical 1D compound showing an independent MONT with 1D → 2D interdigital topology.
elements.clean_text: In order to design 1D MONTs, the linking mode of the organic ligand should accord with the coordination geometry of the metal ion. An effective strategy for this is that the organic ligands first link metal ions to generate a polygon as the subunit, and then, the subunits are connected to the second organic ligands to form a 1D nanotubular framework. By using this synthetic strategy, Sun and co-workers have reported an attractive {[Zn(ATIBDC)(bpy)]⋅3H2O} n  [ATIBDC =5-amino-2,4,6-triiodoisophthalic] MONT with a squares framework. Lately, a novel {[Cd3(phen)3(HL)2(H2O)2]⋅4.25H2O} n  [HL =4,4'-(1,4-phenylene)bis(2,6-dimethyl-3,5-pyridinedi-carboxylic acid)] MONT with 63 topology also has been reported by Huang and co-workers. 1,3-Adamantanedicarboxylic acid (H2ADC) is a V-shaped ligand, and the angle between the coordinating sites is ca. 110° and can be used effectively for the construction of a polygon, which enhances the possibility of formation of a nanotubular framework. However, on the basis of mixed organic ligands, constructing independent 1D MONTs usually requires a terminal ligand as the secondary ligand. A long flexible ligand (bpp) acts as the secondary ligand to construct an independent one-dimensional MONT which has not been reported before. We herein present a novel {[Cd2(ADC)2(bpp)3(H2O)]2⋅8H2O} n  (MONT-1) [bpp =1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane], which is, to our knowledge, the first example of a mesohelical 1D compound showing an independent MONT with 1D → 2D interdigital topology.

elements.content: (a) The coordination environments of the Cd(II) ions in MONT-1; (b) the coordination modes of the H2ADC ligand in complex.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The coordination environments of the Cd(II) ions in MONT-1; (b) the coordination modes of the H2ADC ligand in complex.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that MONT-1 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric P1̅ space group. The asymmetric unit consists of two independent Cd(II) atoms, as shown in Figure a. The geometry around the Cd1 atom can be described as a distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry [CdN3O4] and is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two different ADC ligands, and three nitrogen atoms from three bpp ligands [Cd1−N 2.374(6)−2.436(6) Å, Cd1−O 2.310(5)−2.551(6) Å]. The Cd2 atom has distorted octahedral coordination geometry, and the six basal positions are filled with O2, O5, O6 atoms from two ADC ligands, O5W from one coordinated water molecule, and two N atoms (N1, N5) of two bpp. The Cd2−N bond lengths from 2.319(7) to 2.337(6) Å, and the Cd2−O bond lengths fall in the range 2.250(5)−2.457(5) Å. All the bond lengths are in agreement with those reported in other Cd(II) complexes of N,O-mixed ligands. In complex 1, completely deprotonated ADC ligands take two coordination modes (Figure b) and connect to two cadmium ions. Thus, four cadmium ions are first linked by four ADC ligands to generate a [Cd4(ADC)4] square with a Cd···Cd distance of 9.374(3) Å (Figure a), which is similar to those found in other molecular squares.
elements.clean_text: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that MONT-1 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric P1̅ space group. The asymmetric unit consists of two independent Cd(II) atoms, as shown in Figure a. The geometry around the Cd1 atom can be described as a distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry [CdN3O4] and is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two different ADC ligands, and three nitrogen atoms from three bpp ligands [Cd1-N 2.374(6)-2.436(6) Å, Cd1-O 2.310(5)-2.551(6) Å]. The Cd2 atom has distorted octahedral coordination geometry, and the six basal positions are filled with O2, O5, O6 atoms from two ADC ligands, O5W from one coordinated water molecule, and two N atoms (N1, N5) of two bpp. The Cd2-N bond lengths from 2.319(7) to 2.337(6) Å, and the Cd2-O bond lengths fall in the range 2.250(5)-2.457(5) Å. All the bond lengths are in agreement with those reported in other Cd(II) complexes of N,O-mixed ligands. In complex 1, completely deprotonated ADC ligands take two coordination modes (Figure b) and connect to two cadmium ions. Thus, four cadmium ions are first linked by four ADC ligands to generate a [Cd4(ADC)4] square with a Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distance of 9.374(3) Å (Figure a), which is similar to those found in other molecular squares.

elements.content: It is noteworthy that the long flexible bpp ligand in MONT-1 can be classified into two types according to their contributions to the framework formation [bpp1 and bpp2]. The bpp1 acts as a bridging linker to connect two cadmium ions. Thus, the [Cd4(ADC)4] squares are infinitely connected by bpp1 ligands along the a axis to give rise to a 1D MONT containing [Cd8(ADC)8(bpp1)4] boxes (Figure b) with dimensions of 12.778 × 13.850 Å2 (Cd···Cd). Moreover, an eight-membered water cluster is located in the middle of the [Cd4(ADC)4] square (Figure c). The average O···O distance is 2.770 Å, which is similar to that in the reported supramolecular (H2O)12 morphology. The presence of the (H2O)8 cluster in the compound can stabilize its supramolecular structure due to hydrogen bond formation. Because of the existence of an obstructive mesohelical structure, the MONT-1 architecture only has a void of 10.1% (315.7 Å3 out of the unit cell of 3138.0 Å3), as calculated by PLATON. The second type is that the bpp2 ligand adopts a unidentate coordination mode, so these 1D motifs are decorated with bpp2 ligands at two sides in an outward fashion (Figure d). This unusual binding fashion of bpp2 leads to a fascinating type of 1D → 2D interdigital architecture with side arms. A representation of the beautiful topology is presented in Figure .

The bpp1 acts as a bridging linker to connect two cadmium ions. Thus, the [Cd4(ADC)4] squares are infinitely connected by bpp1 ligands along the a axis to give rise to a 1D MONT containing [Cd8(ADC)8(bpp1)4] boxes (Figure b) with dimensions of 12.778 × 13.850 Å2 (Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd). Moreover, an eight-membered water cluster is located in the middle of the [Cd4(ADC)4] square (Figure c). The average O⋅⋅⋅O distance is 2.770 Å, which is similar to that in the reported supramolecular (H2O)12 morphology. The presence of the (H2O)8 cluster in the compound can stabilize its supramolecular structure due to hydrogen bond formation. Because of the existence of an obstructive mesohelical structure, the MONT-1 architecture only has a void of 10.1% (315.7 Å3 out of the unit cell of 3138.0 Å3), as calculated by PLATON. The second type is that the bpp2 ligand adopts a unidentate coordination mode, so these 1D motifs are decorated with bpp2 ligands at two sides in an outward fashion (Figure d). This unusual binding fashion of bpp2 leads to a fascinating type of 1D → 2D interdigital architecture with side arms. A representation of the beautiful topology is presented in Figure .

elements.content: (a) [Cd4(ADC)4] square; (b) [Cd8(ADC)8(bpp1)4] box; (c) [Cd4(ADC)4] square trapped the (H2O)8 cluster; (d) 1D nanotube of MONT-1 along the a axis (bpp1 is substituted by blue sticks for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) [Cd4(ADC)4] square; (b) [Cd8(ADC)8(bpp1)4] box; (c) [Cd4(ADC)4] square trapped the (H2O)8 cluster; (d) 1D nanotube of MONT-1 along the a axis (bpp1 is substituted by blue sticks for clarity).

elements.content: Fascinating type of 1D → 2D interdigital architecture with side arms. bpp and ADC are substituted by sticks.
elements.clean_text: 3  Fascinating type of 1D → 2D interdigital architecture with side arms. bpp and ADC are substituted by sticks.

elements.content: The flexible bpp ligand can assume different conformations defined by quite different N-to-N distances (TT 9.1−10.1 Å, TG 8.6−9.2 Å, GG′ 6.7−8.6 Å, and GG 3.9 Å). In this complex, bpp1 takes the TG and TT conformations (N-to-N 8.660 and 9.518 Å) and acts as a bidentate bridge for two cadmium atoms. Usually, long flexible ligands (bpp) lead to interpenetrating structures and helical modes. Very interestingly, the MONT-1 coexists as two kinds of helical chains running along the a axis, a left-handed and a right-handed helical chain [−Cd1−ADC−Cd2−bpp1−Cd1−] with an equal pitch of 12.935 Å, resulting in a mesohelical 1D organic−inorganic hybrid framework, as illustrated in Figure . It is noticed that the MONT-1 presents the first independent 1D MONT with mesohelical structure according to our knowledge. Furthermore, the intrinsic interest in this type is the discrete molecular tube [Cd8(ADC)8(bpp)8] n line-up to generate a pipeline structure that extends along the b direction (). These pipes stack side-by-side in the ab plane to form a layer. One potential driving force for the alignment of the tubes is hydrogen-bonding interactions (O5W···O3 =2.726 Å).
elements.clean_text: The flexible bpp ligand can assume different conformations defined by quite different N-to-N distances (TT 9.1-10.1 Å, TG 8.6-9.2 Å, GG' 6.7-8.6 Å, and GG 3.9 Å). In this complex, bpp1 takes the TG and TT conformations (N-to-N 8.660 and 9.518 Å) and acts as a bidentate bridge for two cadmium atoms. Usually, long flexible ligands (bpp) lead to interpenetrating structures and helical modes. Very interestingly, the MONT-1 coexists as two kinds of helical chains running along the a axis, a left-handed and a right-handed helical chain [-Cd1-ADC-Cd2-bpp1-Cd1-] with an equal pitch of 12.935 Å, resulting in a mesohelical 1D organic-inorganic hybrid framework, as illustrated in Figure . It is noticed that the MONT-1 presents the first independent 1D MONT with mesohelical structure according to our knowledge. Furthermore, the intrinsic interest in this type is the discrete molecular tube [Cd8(ADC)8(bpp)8] n  line-up to generate a pipeline structure that extends along the b direction (). These pipes stack side-by-side in the ab plane to form a layer. One potential driving force for the alignment of the tubes is hydrogen-bonding interactions (O5W⋅⋅⋅O3 =2.726 Å).

elements.content: A left-handed (L) and a right-handed helical chain (R) in MONT-1.
elements.clean_text: 4  A left-handed (L) and a right-handed helical chain (R) in MONT-1.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) indicates that MONT-1 is stable up to 280 °C (), while the first weight loss of 5.20% from room temperature to 180 °C corresponds to the loss of all the guest water molecules (calcd 5.31%). From 180 to 230 °C, the TGA curve of 1 passes through a flat area, and then a weight loss of 1.26% is detected over the range 230−270 °C, corresponding to the loss of the coordinated water molecule (calcd: 1.33%). Additionally, to confirm the stability of MONT-1, we examined the sample by X-ray diffraction powder (XRPD) analysis. Corresponding to the TG analysis of 1, the original sample was heated at 200 and 250 °C for 5 h, and the XRPD patterns are similar to that of the original sample (), although minor differences can be seen in the positions, intensities, and widths of some peaks, which indicates that the framework structure remains intact after removing all water molecules.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) indicates that MONT-1 is stable up to 280 °C (), while the first weight loss of 5.20% from room temperature to 180 °C corresponds to the loss of all the guest water molecules (calcd 5.31%). From 180 to 230 °C, the TGA curve of 1 passes through a flat area, and then a weight loss of 1.26% is detected over the range 230-270 °C, corresponding to the loss of the coordinated water molecule (calcd: 1.33%). Additionally, to confirm the stability of MONT-1, we examined the sample by X-ray diffraction powder (XRPD) analysis. Corresponding to the TG analysis of 1, the original sample was heated at 200 and 250 °C for 5 h, and the XRPD patterns are similar to that of the original sample (), although minor differences can be seen in the positions, intensities, and widths of some peaks, which indicates that the framework structure remains intact after removing all water molecules.

elements.content: The luminescent properties of the original compound 1 and dehydrated sample 1a (after being heated at 200 °C for 5 h, the guest water molecules have been removed as evidenced by TGA ()) were investigated in the solid state. The emission spectra are shown in Figure (the test conditions are the same in compounds 1 and 1a: the excitation wave in both is 280 nm; the width of the slide in excitation and emission is 10 nm; the test voltage is 700 V and the scan speed is 240 nm/min). The emission spectrum for 1 shows a main peak at 350 nm and two shoulder peaks at 387 and 449 nm with λex =280 nm. The shoulder peak at 449 nm is probably due to ligand donation because a very weak, similar peak at 446 nm also appears for the free bpp ligand (λex =350 nm for bpp, the solid H2ADC ligand does not possess any luminiscence at room temperature). The main peak at 350 nm and another shoulder peak at 387 nm are blue-shifted relative to that of the pure bpp ligand and may be assigned to ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT) bands because the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) is presumably the π-bonding orbital from the pyridylic rings, and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) is associated mainly with the Cd−O (carboxylate) σ*-antibonding orbital, which is localized mostly on the metal centers. However, the spectrum of 1a is similar to that of complex 1, but the intensity is weaker and the main peak of 1a is blue-shifted by about 27 nm compared to compound 1. The above luminescent phenomenon is presumably owing to the framework architecture of 1, which is more rigid than that of 1a. In the original crystal, abundant lattice water molecules fill the network, forming important weak forces, which not only stabilize the framework and enhance the rigid structure, but also affect the transfer of energy effectively from bpp to the metal center. Accordingly, some guest molecules are removed from the MOF when heated, undoubtedly decreasing the weak interactions. Therefore, the emission spectrum becomes weaker, and the main peak is shifted. Moreover, this compound exhibits blue-shift emission with large intensity enhancement compared with that of the free ligand. So the MONT-1 may be suitable as a candidate of luminescent materials.

The emission spectra are shown in Figure  (the test conditions are the same in compounds 1 and 1a: the excitation wave in both is 280 nm; the width of the slide in excitation and emission is 10 nm; the test voltage is 700 V and the scan speed is 240 nm/min). The emission spectrum for 1 shows a main peak at 350 nm and two shoulder peaks at 387 and 449 nm with λex =280 nm. The shoulder peak at 449 nm is probably due to ligand donation because a very weak, similar peak at 446 nm also appears for the free bpp ligand (λex =350 nm for bpp, the solid H2ADC ligand does not possess any luminiscence at room temperature). The main peak at 350 nm and another shoulder peak at 387 nm are blue-shifted relative to that of the pure bpp ligand and may be assigned to ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT) bands because the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) is presumably the π-bonding orbital from the pyridylic rings, and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) is associated mainly with the Cd-O (carboxylate) σ*-antibonding orbital, which is localized mostly on the metal centers. However, the spectrum of 1a is similar to that of complex 1, but the intensity is weaker and the main peak of 1a is blue-shifted by about 27 nm compared to compound 1. The above luminescent phenomenon is presumably owing to the framework architecture of 1, which is more rigid than that of 1a. Accordingly, some guest molecules are removed from the MOF when heated, undoubtedly decreasing the weak interactions. Therefore, the emission spectrum becomes weaker, and the main peak is shifted. Moreover, this compound exhibits blue-shift emission with large intensity enhancement compared with that of the free ligand. So the MONT-1 may be suitable as a candidate of luminescent materials.

elements.content: The solid-state photoluminescent spectra of compound 1, 1a, and the bpp ligand at room temperature (under the same measurement conditions).
elements.clean_text: 5  The solid-state photoluminescent spectra of compound 1, 1a, and the bpp ligand at room temperature (under the same measurement conditions).

elements.content: In summary, through rational design by selecting the appropriate metal center and bridging ligand we have successfully synthesized and structurally characterized one unusual independent 1D metal−organic nanotube with mesohelical structure. Preliminary thermal and fluorescence experiments show that MONT-1 possesses strong fluorescent property and thermal stability and then can be explored for potential blue luminescent materials.
elements.clean_text: In summary, through rational design by selecting the appropriate metal center and bridging ligand we have successfully synthesized and structurally characterized one unusual independent 1D metal-organic nanotube with mesohelical structure. Preliminary thermal and fluorescence experiments show that MONT-1 possesses strong fluorescent property and thermal stability and then can be explored for potential blue luminescent materials.

elements.content:
CCDC 749072 number for 1. Additional figures and the supplementary crystallographic data in CIF for this paper. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

References

A mixture of H2ADC (0.10 mmol, 22.4 mg), bpp (0.10 mmol, 19.8 mg) in 5 mL of CH3OH was layered onto a solution of Cd(NO3)2 ·4H2O (0.10 mmol, 30.8 mg) in 5 mL of H2O. One month later, colorless block crystals of 1 were collected. Yield: 52%.

cln_elements.content:
It is noteworthy that the long flexible bpp ligand in MONT-1 can be classified into two types according to their contributions to the framework formation [bpp1 and bpp2]. The bpp1 acts as a bridging linker to connect two cadmium ions. Thus, the [Cd4(ADC)4] squares are infinitely connected by bpp1 ligands along the a axis to give rise to a 1D MONT containing [Cd8(ADC)8(bpp1)4] boxes (Figure b) with dimensions of 12.778 × 13.850 Å2 (Cd···Cd). Moreover, an eight-membered water cluster is located in the middle of the [Cd4(ADC)4] square (Figure c). The average O···O distance is 2.770 Å, which is similar to that in the reported supramolecular (H2O)12 morphology. The presence of the (H2O)8 cluster in the compound can stabilize its supramolecular structure due to hydrogen bond formation. Because of the existence of an obstructive mesohelical structure, the MONT-1 architecture only has a void of 10.1% (315.7 Å3 out of the unit cell of 3138.0 Å3), as calculated by PLATON. The second type is that the bpp2 ligand adopts a unidentate coordination mode, so these 1D motifs are decorated with bpp2 ligands at two sides in an outward fashion (Figure d). This unusual binding fashion of bpp2 leads to a fascinating type of 1D → 2D interdigital architecture with side arms. A representation of the beautiful topology is presented in Figure .

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) indicates that MONT-1 is stable up to 280 °C (), while the first weight loss of 5.20% from room temperature to 180 °C corresponds to the loss of all the guest water molecules (calcd 5.31%). From 180 to 230 °C, the TGA curve of 1 passes through a flat area, and then a weight loss of 1.26% is detected over the range 230−270 °C, corresponding to the loss of the coordinated water molecule (calcd: 1.33%). Additionally, to confirm the stability of MONT-1, we examined the sample by X-ray diffraction powder (XRPD) analysis. Corresponding to the TG analysis of 1, the original sample was heated at 200 and 250 °C for 5 h, and the XRPD patterns are similar to that of the original sample (), although minor differences can be seen in the positions, intensities, and widths of some peaks, which indicates that the framework structure remains intact after removing all water molecules.

It is noteworthy that the long flexible bpp ligand in MONT-1 can be classified into two types according to their contributions to the framework formation [bpp1 and bpp2]. The bpp1 acts as a bridging linker to connect two cadmium ions. Thus, the [Cd4(ADC)4] squares are infinitely connected by bpp1 ligands along the a axis to give rise to a 1D MONT containing [Cd8(ADC)8(bpp1)4] boxes (Figure b) with dimensions of 12.778 × 13.850 Å2 (Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd). Moreover, an eight-membered water cluster is located in the middle of the [Cd4(ADC)4] square (Figure c). The average O⋅⋅⋅O distance is 2.770 Å, which is similar to that in the reported supramolecular (H2O)12 morphology. The presence of the (H2O)8 cluster in the compound can stabilize its supramolecular structure due to hydrogen bond formation. Because of the existence of an obstructive mesohelical structure, the MONT-1 architecture only has a void of 10.1% (315.7 Å3 out of the unit cell of 3138.0 Å3), as calculated by PLATON. The second type is that the bpp2 ligand adopts a unidentate coordination mode, so these 1D motifs are decorated with bpp2 ligands at two sides in an outward fashion (Figure d). This unusual binding fashion of bpp2 leads to a fascinating type of 1D → 2D interdigital architecture with side arms. A representation of the beautiful topology is presented in Figure .

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) indicates that MONT-1 is stable up to 280 °C (), while the first weight loss of 5.20% from room temperature to 180 °C corresponds to the loss of all the guest water molecules (calcd 5.31%). From 180 to 230 °C, the TGA curve of 1 passes through a flat area, and then a weight loss of 1.26% is detected over the range 230-270 °C, corresponding to the loss of the coordinated water molecule (calcd: 1.33%). Additionally, to confirm the stability of MONT-1, we examined the sample by X-ray diffraction powder (XRPD) analysis. Corresponding to the TG analysis of 1, the original sample was heated at 200 and 250 °C for 5 h, and the XRPD patterns are similar to that of the original sample (), although minor differences can be seen in the positions, intensities, and widths of some peaks, which indicates that the framework structure remains intact after removing all water molecules.

decomposition temperature.type: loss of all the guest water molecules
loss of the coordinated water molecule

metadata.title: An Unusual Independent 1D Metal−Organic Nanotube with Mesohelical Structure and 1D → 2D Interdigitation
